**Short answer** – The overwhelming scientific and medical consensus is that the benefits of routine childhood vaccines far outweigh their risks. The reasons doctors recommend them are rooted in a large, repeatedly‑replicated body of evidence showing that vaccines prevent serious disease, death, and long‑term disability, and that they are *extremely* safe for the vast majority of children. At the same time, a small‑to‑moderate minority of clinicians, researchers, and members of the public raise questions about specific safety signals, the optimal timing of doses, and the adequacy of long‑term follow‑up. Below is a systematic presentation of the strongest evidence from **all** sides, together with a clear indication of where expert agreement lies, where debate persists, and which points are often misunderstood or omitted. --- ## 1. Why doctors (and public‑health agencies) recommend vaccinating children | Primary rationale | What the evidence shows (strength of evidence) | Consensus rating* | |--------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------| | **A. Prevent acute illness** – vaccines stop children from getting the diseases they target (measles, pertussis, polio, rotavirus, etc.). | • Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and post‑licensure studies show >90 % efficacy for most childhood vaccines (e.g., MMR 97 % after two doses, DTaP 92 % against pertussis‑related hospitalisation).
• Population‑level data: after introduction of the Hib vaccine, invasive Hib disease fell >99 % in the U.S. (CDC, 2020).
• Modelling studies estimate that the 2021 U.S. birth cohort will avoid >30 million cases of vaccine‑preventable disease over the first 20 years of life. | **Very high** | | **B. Prevent severe complications & death** – many vaccine‑preventable diseases cause encephalitis, permanent disability, or death. | • Measles can cause sub‑acute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) in 1‑10 /100 000 infections; vaccination eliminates that risk.
• Pertussis in infants <6 months carries a case‑fatality rate of 1‑2 %; the DTaP series reduces infant hospitalisation by ~80 % (meta‑analysis, 2021).
• Polio paralytic disease eliminated in >99 % of countries after global vaccination campaigns. | **Very high** | | **C. Herd (community) immunity** – vaccinating enough people protects those who cannot be vaccinated (e.g., newborns, immune‑compromised). | • The critical vaccination threshold (CVT) for measles is ≈95 % coverage; when coverage falls below this, outbreaks re‑emerge (e.g., 2019 U.S. measles surge).
• Studies of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) show indirect protection of unvaccinated adults, reducing invasive disease by 30‑40 %. | **Very high** | | **D. Economic & societal benefits** – fewer sick days, reduced health‑care costs, higher educational attainment. | • A 2020 CDC cost‑effectiveness analysis estimates that routine childhood vaccination saves $13 billion annually in direct medical costs in the U.S. alone, plus $10 billion in societal costs.
• Long‑term cohort studies link severe early‑life infections (e.g., rotavirus gastroenteritis) with later neurodevelopmental delays; vaccination reduces that risk. | **High** |
